Welcome to /k/, 4chan's weapons board. Our board centers around weapons, armor, and other myriad military technology. While guns are the primary topic, threads involving any other sort of weapons, from swords and knives to tanks and jet fighters, come up frequently as well. If you're new, we suggest reading the sticky at http://amagicalplace.wikia.com/wiki/Sticky to get acquainted with the board's subject matter.

Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
having bought a couple of old collectible firearms I've noticed a pattern: people tend to take great care of the outside, but on the inside there are pockets that never, ever get any attention and those will very slowly rust.

here's the magazine tube of a Winchester Model 71 deluxe. outside finish is like new. inside is 99%. magazine tube? probably not unscrewed since it was screwed in by the factory. it's not even complicated, just remove some screws (with a proper gun screwdriver kit!) once cleaned up it will look almost new, but the oil I'm using for cleaning (brunox turbo spray) wiping of reddish-brown tells me what I'm doing now should have been done decades ago.

disassemble your firearms. every surface made of steel (even stainless), especially those you never see when it's assembled, needs a protective coating or it will inevitably rust. those screws holding buttplate and sling swivel in the stock are rusting right now, unless you conserved them. the factory sure didn't.

I use calcium sulfonate grease for the inside and renaissance wax for the outside/stock parts. it's one of those things you do once right. don't be the guy with rusty threads.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous thread: >>56103219

>What is reloading?
Reloading or handloading is the practice of making firearm cartridges by assembling the individual components (case, primer, propellant, and projectile), rather than purchasing factory-assembled ammunition.

>Why would I want to reload?
There are three main reasons to start reloading: cost, quality and availability. Generally speaking, reloading can be a cheaper than buying ammo so if you shoot a lot you might save some money. With reloading, you can tailor the ammunition to your particular firearm increasing quality (e.g. accuracy, effect on target). Finally, some calibers just don't have factory ammo anymore (e.g. .577-450 Martini) or the ammo is hideously expensive, so you need to load your own if you actually want to shoot them.
Reloading can also be a complementary hobby to guns themselves. Don't expect to make or save money reloading, you'll just be shooting more.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous >>56077364
Happy Thanksgiving & Black Friday edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

last_replies.com: How big of a difference is the bayonet mount vs j arm mount? I have a wilcox g11 but and tempted to pick up a g24.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56162266
I guess you meant to compare to bayonet and dovetail j-arm mounting interface.
Bayonet interface is considered to be a looser fitting mechanism that is usually the source of people's dislike of the rattling of their NVD. The bayonet is also very easy to trip the disconnection lever when you are trying to adjust your NVD and/or lowering arm mount, causing your NVD to drop towards the ground.
Dovetail is much more secure feeling with no play at all in the physical connection to the lowering arm socket. The lever/button to disconnect the dovetail interface is recessed in the socket and is practically impossible to engage on accident.

If you are satisficed with the bayonet interface and the G11 lowering arm mount, I don't think you should upgrade/sidegrade unless you got money to spare for a legit G24 and a new dovetail j-arm.

To be fair, by the end of 1941, nearly two million Soviet soldiers had already been murdered in captivity through willful and malicious neglect alone. The overwhelming majority of German soldiers on the Eastern Front were aware of this to at least some degree. They had no reason to believe that the Soviets would be merciful, especially after Germany was forced on the backfoot and started losing ground (thereby exposing the Soviets to the full extent of German atrocities). It became a self-fulfilling prophecy of sorts. The Germans, aware of their own sins, believed that the Soviets would show them no quarter and fought on savagely, causing the Soviets to become increasingly savage out of sheer frustration.

The 1993 film Stalingrad summed up the German soldier's dilemma regarding surrender perfectly.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56156486
No.
In millimetres, the most common shot-size (cartridge size) is 12x70.
The next comes the longer x76, and some hunting shotguns even support x89.

Your shotgun's chamber length determines how long shells you can safely use. My Moss500A for example is 12x76, max.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56153383
Just about anything half decent will work for you.

>>56154098
Scope or red dot wouldn't make much sense for ducks or stuff, but it could be a great addition if you're gonna hunt some non-flying animal with slugs. You can get a rifled barrel for spin stabilizing smooth slugs, which together with a suitable optic would give you essentially a very large bore rifle. Very good for destroying wild hogs, among other things. If you like optics that is, personally I don't and prefer aperture iron sights for fine precision, but you may be different.

Sling is good to have. Shell holders are practical, though don't bother with those shell loops on slings, loading from those are really fucking awkward, put one on the left side of the receiver, and then wear a bandolier over your chest, and you've got the shells you need for a hunt or for defending your home.
A mounted light would be very useful for your home defense gun, so consider that at some point.
